Preparations are now under way
for the second Peace Oratorial contest among the colleges of Maryland. The arrangements are in the
hands of a committee of the Arbitration Society, consisting of John
S. Dickinson, '13, chairman; J. C.
Sinclair, '13; and A. L. Hammond,
.14.
The contest will be under the
auspices of the Intercollegiate Peace
Association, and will take place in
McCoy Hall on Friday, February
16, at 8 P. M.
This contest, for which the Maryland Peace Society gives a first
Prize of seventy-five dollars and a
second prize of fifty dollars, is open
to a representative of each of the
colleges of the State. The first contest was held last year—St. John's,
Washington College, Georgetown
:University and. Hopkins being 'represented. The first prize was won
by Mr. Bobbitt of Hopkins and the
second prize by the representative
Of Georgetown.
Similar contests are held in many
other States, particularly in the
West. The winners in the various
State contests generally compete in
a national contest at the annual
meeting of the American Peace
Association. Last year this meeting was. held at Hopkins, and Baltimoreans had an opportunity to
Witness the contest, and to judge
of the oratory displayed.

The football schedule came up for
further discussion and the board was
not a little surprised to learn from Manager Lile that Johns Hopkins had declined an offer to play on Lambeth Field
next fall. It was fully expected that
the Hopkins management would readily
consent to a return game. It looks now
as if the athletic relations, so pleasantly
inaugurated between the two institutions last year, would be severed and
that there will be no gridiron contest
next fall, either in Charlottesville or
Baltimore.

Graduate Manager Holmes and
the other football officials denied
this. The original tentative agreement with Virginia provided that
all games should be played at
Homewood, as much larger crowds
would attend than if the contest •
should be held at Charlottesville.
In spite of this agreement, Virginia
insisted that the game next fall be
played on their home grounds.
Hopkins was so anxious to get a
return game, that it was agreed that
if a guarantee of $6o0 be given the
contest would be at Charlottesville,
and Virginia would permitted to
disregard the tentative agreement,
which made it obligatory to play at
Homewood.
This offer was refused by Virginia, although when they came to
Baltimore last November they were
given $303 expenses and half of
the net receipts after the Hopkins
expenses had been deducted, making a total of $9oo. This was the
most advantageous financial arrangement which any visiting team
has ever made with Hopkins.

under that of editor, translator,
comp:ler, series, title and subject,
so that within reasonable limits
every searcher may be satisfied, no
matter what his purpose or how exact his knowledge is. This catalogue is being made in obedience
to a code of rules upon which the
British and American Library Associat:ons came to substantial agreement in 1908. The English speaking world catalogues this way.
Moreover, even the size of the card
selected (7 2x1272cm.). is the international standard one now. This
is of importance, for a good percentage of our cards can be secured already printed by outside
agencies, both here and abroad, and
they all use this size of card. The
scope of such help is going to
widen cont:nually. National and
international co-operation is a live
topic in library circles these days.
So important is this source of aid,
present and prospective, that even
if our old catalogue had all virtue
(which it has not, for it is its defects that form the mainspring Of
our present un(lertakings) there
would be a strong argument in
favor of rewriting it on the larger
cards, so that we might be in position to reap the advantage of cooperative or centralized card-printing. In fact, Harvard and Columbia are doing so today for this very
reason. The subject headings used
in our catalogue are chosen from
lists distributed by the Library of
Congress.
But no matter how efficient the
catalogue and its attendant may be
in turning up the title of a book
desired, what is the profit if we
cannot then find the book? Accordingly, we are assigning to each
volume a symbol which, being repeated on its main card in the catalogue, will guide us to it. Each of
these silent inhabitants of our
shelves has his own house number.
In probably all libraries nowadays, books are grouped by topics.
I 1 ere is caste rigid as the Orient's.
Shakespeare ad Euclid will not be
neighbors. In practically every
large collection, books are preserved in their places and located
by a system of notation applied to
them. But a radically new method
was formulated about the time our
University was founded. Before
that period it was the shelf that received numeration. The book was
designated by the number of the
shelf on which it stood. Both the
Peabody and the Enoch Pratt libraries of this city give illustrations of this method. Thus with

such a number as —1234 in a Peabody book, the minus sign tells that
it is on the left side of the building,
while i indicates the floor, 2 the
alcove, 3 the press, and 4 the shelf,
where the volume is to be found.
Such a scheme were unexcelled if
only the 'librarian could be omniscient, i. e., if he could at the beginning so allot shelf room to subjects
that the empty space left at the end
of each for growth would be filled
at the same moment a generation
later. But this does not happen. A
subject uses up all its space, but it
cannot dislodge its more slowly
growing neighbor except at the expense of changing all the latter's
call numbers. Hence, it leaps in
its extension to some other empty
place in the library, and thus its
continuity is broken. Finally, we
get a crazy-quilt effect, which is
most disconcerting to readers and
staff, if the time comes when for
any reason the,former are admitted
freely to the shelves. Therefore,
in place of this system of "fixed
location," there has come into vogue
that pf "relative location," whereby not the shelves but the subjects
are numbered. If the subjectgroups are assigned letters or
numbers in sequence, A or No.
preceding B or No. 2, such letters or numbers will always disclose the whereabouts of the books
to us, no matter how unevenly the
subjects grow, or how many structural changes the building may
undergo. Book-notation is not then
the simple task of numbering library furniture, but it is the encyclopedic one of classifying the
whole field of human knowledge,
as recorded in books, and numbering in logical order every division
of the scheme. There are various
systems of classification in existence. The one most widely known
is the decimal plan of Melvil
Dewey. We have adopted here the
schedules being worked out at the
Library of Congress. In this,
twenty-one large subjects are designate by the letters of the alphabet, except I, 0, W, X, Y. In
most of these twenty-one subjects a few main sub-divisiOlis are
designated by adding a second letter to the first. Thus Q is Science, QA Mathematics, QB Astronomy, QC Physics, QD Chemistry, QE Geology, etc. Further
sub-divisions are indicated by running numbers from i to 9999 if
necessary, and even these fine topics can be split indefinitely by the
use of decimals. For example.
QA is Mathematics, QAI is
Mathematical. jourtials, QA 17I is
Theory of groups, QA552 is Plane
analytic geometry, etc., etc.
Now, every book on the same
topic has the same class number,
or familyname, as we may say.

Football Relations With Virginia.

If the announcements in Saturday's Washing-ton papers concerning the break between Hopkins and
Virginia are to be believed, Roosevelt's Annanias Club shouldn't be
confined to individuals, for a certain college football management
is clamoring for admittance.
Last November, because a Hopkins-Virginia game at Homewood
would prove to be a big drawing
card, and because it was deemed
desirable to establish football relations with the Charlottesville institution, we agreed to terms which
were grossly unfair to ourselves,
and which conceded everything
to Virginia.
First of all, we agreed to a fouryear rule, which handicapped us
considerably and which was responsible for the bad defeat which we
got. Although Carlisle, the Navy,
Gettysburg, and Stevens and the
Maryland colleges meet us with no
conditions, Virginia, with her peculiar self-favoring standards of athletic'honor, could not play at Homewood unless she were given the
advantages which she demanded—
advantages which practically dezided the game in advance.
,
And when the game was lost,
Hopkins, with true spirit, uttered
no squeal. "Virginia outclassed us,"
was the way THE NEws-LETTER
put it, and there was not a word
said of the injustice the four-year

designated by the number of the
shelf on which it stood. Both the
Peabody and the Enoch Pratt libraries of this city give illustrations of this method. Thus with

that the empty space left at the end
of each for growth would be filled

subject uses up all its space, but it

not nominated, the Woodrow Wilson League of College Men will
Pass out of existence. Maybe it is
better after all to wait and see who
the candidate is going to be. Then
it will be time enough to form a
Hopkins organization ,to help along
his candidacy.
